Subjective: Back pain, right-sided, radiating posterior/lateral right thigh/lower leg to foot. Onset 1.5 weeks ago, worsening. Constant pain, all day. Unable to sleep, awake for nights. Dull sensation outer right lower leg, tingling. Pain with lifting heavy objects at work (supermarket). Temporarily stopped working, difficulty exercising. Paracetamol, ibuprofen (max doses) ineffective. No loss of strength in leg. Normal sensation 'riding breeches' area. Normal bladder/bowel function. No smoking/alcohol. Request: Wants pain relief, wants to sleep, asks about scans/surgery.
Objective: Pain on movement (getting on couch). Inspection: Legs (L/R) symmetrical, no back abnormalities. Palpation: Back normal, no vertebral tenderness. Pain noted towards 'bum and behind it.' Right Straight Leg Raise: Painful. Left SLR: Normal. Sensation: Dullness outer right lower leg vs. left. Motor Strength: Strength present bilaterally, but right leg movement painful. Reflexes: All good (Achilles, Babinski).
Assessment: Lumbosacral radicular syndrome, susp. Herniated Nucleus Pulposus (HNP). No signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: Explanation: Hernia (disc compressing nerve), nerve pain, long recovery (weeks-months). Surgery not first line, similar long-term outcomes.
Meds: Start Pregabalin, slow dose build-up. Driving restriction: 1 week after starting/dose increase, or with side effects.
Lifestyle: Physiotherapy for exercises to improve flexibility, aid disc regression.
Safety Net: Contact sooner if: worsening symptoms, abnormal 'riding breeches' sensation, bladder/bowel dysfunction, significant leg weakness.
Follow-up: Phone call in 1 week to review pain relief.
